author: Slow Hand
content: I'm looking into manufacturing them right now for people in the LA area, but my concern is infringing on their patent and putting myself in a position where they can legally shut us down. Is anyone here familiar with how the US patent system works? I don't yet know how to determine how closely we can copy their design and where we'd need to deviate.

author: absflores
content: Maybe upload what you found and we can all try lol

author: Slow Hand
content: So for me the question is "what are the defining characteristics of this patent that are exclusive to and cannot be copied?" Is it the shape of the trap? Is it the half/half absorptive/reflective surfaces? Is it something else?

content: oooo. If everything works put patent wise... would you ship out side of LA as well?

author: Slow Hand
content:
When they’re available everyone here will be the first to know. 

I’m sure I’ll have a dozen more questions/feedback for everyone before it’s all done.

author: longstoryshort
content: Careful with patents, I've been in a pretty annoying situation with a wildly successful product that landed me in a bit of trouble.  I changed the product, not much - and the lawyers basically said it comes down to, if we were to put it in front of a jury and ask them if there was a discerning difference between the two, you're going to have 100k in lawyer fees just to have them say "great, they look the same

author: longstoryshort

author: eliotpeace
content: Any Audeze LCD X users in here? Would love to hear a seasoned review of your experience with them (:

author: Adam Thein
content:
Hey!  I've been using mine since last May (2021 update version)!  Quick review on a scale of 1-10

Comfort: 5/10 - I've gotten used to the weight but they are by no means a comfortable headphone
Detail: 10/10 - unholy transient and texture detail retrieval
Translation: 8/10 - my low end comes back pretty hefty but general smooth, upper midrange I cannot seem to get right without also checking Airpods and my car

Would buy again in a heartbeat though.  I live in an old upstairs apartment where monitors are not an option other than short term low volume listening and rely on these for 90% of my work.

Also, for a full chain explanation I am using Audient id44 -> Schiit Modi/Magni Heresy stack via SPDIF, they don't take a lot of power to run though and could probably run off most audio interface headphone amps

author: eliotpeace
content: @Adam Thein Thank you for the explanation! Yeah, I'm in a similar environment (and will be for the foreseeable future) that prevents from the full monitoring experience. I've been using the LCD 1's for a year now so I don't think the discomfort will be a shocker haha. I'll likely stick to the Apollo Twin X amp, as it's done the job for the LCD 1 planer drivers. Also, I have a $200 discount code for the LCD X's, so I'm 90% sure I'm going to be an owner soon

author: Adam Thein
content: Right on!  Yeah I'd say for $200 off it's a great grab for you especially being familiar with their planar stuff!  I'd just grab them from someplace with a good return policy in case the weight is too much.  It took a couple weeks for me to get used to them coming from Beyerdynamics which were super comfortable to me.  The sound quality upgrade was worth the adjustment though for me!

author: eliotpeace
content: @Adam Thein I think I heard they changed the travel case for the LCD X creator version to some sort of leather bag??? Do you have the hardshell pro case?

author: Adam Thein
content: When I bought them it was probably slightly older inventory before the started adding the case.  So I just got a pad lined cardboard box with mine.  Recently ordered a Geekria case for them just to keep them from getting crushed in a backpack or suitcase.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Yeah I’ve been on LCD-X’s for about a year and a half. 

In terms of pros and cons, I love that they are ruler flat from 5 hz to 1k and super low distortion. That helps me a ton in terms of accurate referencing and hearing wtf is going on in the low end. 

My biggest gripe is that they aren’t very sturdy. Like I’ve literally just been sitting there and had the driver fall off the headband, so the driver falls off my head. I have to tighten the screws on them literally every time I use them because they get so floppy, and I’ve had the screws bend over time so much so that they had to mail me new screws because the original screws no longer even functioned. 

The scooped high mids can take a little getting used to but I tend to mix too relaxed and recessed in the high mids anyways so that actually worked out in my favor. 

All in all, I’d recommend them.

author: Eric Martin
content: I had a pair for a year, did a bunch of work on them. During that time I found them fatiguing both physically and audibly, I did make great work on them but the weight and the upper mid scoop caused me to start using my Shure IEMs instead and I’m much happier now.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
@Will Melones  it's a pretty simple 3 way formula.

speed of sound varies with air pressure and temp but for most calculations it's rounded out to 343m/s (that's meters per second).
the medium chabges the speed a lot. water and other solids change the speed drastically but for us we usually assume air (without heavy gasses) 

formula is
wavelength = speed / frequency 

speed usually doesn't change just for convwntion but if your space is very cold or very hot you might want to consider that. generally things move faster in the cold. 

you can find tables out there for the average size of a lot of common frequencies 

and there's apps like " lambda" and  "sec-hz" that can do most of that.ath for you. pretty sure you can change the speed of sound on them too. I think they're ios o ly but I'm sure there's other options online. 

once you have that info I assume you'd apply it to whatever the building specs are. my bet is you'd be using a subdivision of the wavelength to be able to capture it inside the trap.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Basically none…just enough so the cables can come out of the speakers without getting crushed and the sockets bent haha. At the corners at back of the subs it’s like 2 inches

As per @Nomograph Mastering advice…as I understand this is so the low end stays in phase as much as possible since low freqs are not directional. The shorter distance to wall means a shorter distance for them to bounce since they are also shooting backwards. Thus they meet with the waves going toward listening position ASAP and produce as little phasing of the lows as possible! More complicated than that of course (for example this also makes the bass more present) but it’s the understanding I have 

If you meant just the wood…it’s screwed into the wall so it won’t rattle so there is no space between the wood and the felt (and drywall behind) that it covers

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Yep, what Jack said basically. The best place for speakers is in the wall. The second best is right against the wall

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: As you go down in frequency the speaker becomes more and more Omni directional meaning that more energy wraps around the cabinet and hits the wall reflecting back to the listener. In jack’s case that delayed reflection probably an extra 3 mS but given that the frequencies are low, and hence the wavelengths long it’s not too much of an issue

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ha! I have thought a lot about that exact issue, and cabinet edge diffraction, and SBIR and and and …

author: David Fuller
content:
Wilson speakers are weird. The drivers are exceptional - high end Scanspeak semi-custom jobs - and the distortion shows it. The cabinets are built extremely rigidly.  

Everything else is... Odd. The ports are tuned badly, the cabinets have sharp edges for a diffraction mess, dispersion seems to have not entered into the equation at all.

author: David Fuller
content: A lot of really cool speaker engineering came from home audio focused companies

author: David Fuller
content: I mean shit, most of the good design practices in speakers came from people trying to make speakers sound good in fairly reflective domestic setups

author: David Fuller
content: Turns out a lot of those translate into good studio monitor characteristics

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s definitely been cross pollination so it make sense to keep an ear open

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Hifi hardcore will say studio speakers are built to a price, pro guys will say hifi is woo woo nonsense. Both can be true and false too

author: David Fuller
content: There's a lot of woo woo nonsense in both. I've found that it's just in different places.

author: Slow Hand
content: At this point I've got a PhD in wrapping cables.

author: Slow Hand
content: I've come to find it as a very relaxing activity. Something I can meditate on.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
We should have compared notes yesterday. I've wrapped soooo many cables, especially when working for Eric Valentine because his setups were always so elaborate. I'm fascinated by these seemingly minor but fundamental parts of music making.

I'm an over under wrapper with a fairly tight coil and I always put the soft side out on my cables ties.

author: ALXCPH
content: this is such a respectable and rare skill! the amount of people who dont give a shit about wrapping cables is astounding. they last sooo much longer if you just spend the 5 seconds doing it right!

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm not sure what over/under is exactly, but I was taught early on to roll the cable between my thumb and forefinger as I was coiling it up so that the wire straightened out properly and didn't develop kinks.

I came up doing stagecraft and one quality that was impressed upon us was that you should be able to toss one end of the cable twenty feet across the stage and have it unspool effortlessly in a straight line. 

That's where the rolling between your fingers comes in handy because if the coil is lumpy your cable toss is going to have a poor chance of unraveling smoothly.

author: oaklandmatt
content: Yes! Over under is one of the methods for this. You let the cable rotate the direction it wants for each loop of your spool so it comes out even when you unspool.

author: BatMeckley
content: Next door burned down. Owner had passed, homeless moved in. House in probate. Same basic story has happened to me now on 3 of the four sides of my property. Starting to feel like the grim reaper

author: ALXCPH
content: did u buy property in dantes inferno? wtf

author: BatMeckley
content: I’m the least expensive house in a nice neighborhood with one of the best schools districts in the country. The homeless situation in LA has just gotten out of control

author: ALXCPH
content:
Man it's so heart breaking that one of the wealthiest hubs of the world, live shoulder to shoulder with homeless people. 
It's very alien to me, because here in Denmark, becoming homeless is almost an active choice you have to make, because we have so many systems in place to combat homelessness. 
Our system is definitely not perfect, by any stretch. But LA really seems extreme. Especially with the amount of money in the city. 
this is not meant as a brag, because i don't agree with how things are done here in Denmark politically either. 

I just think the increasing gap between have and not to have is saddening.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Just because I paid for the symphony over the Apollo doesn’t qualify my house as “one of the wealthiest hubs of the world”. 

The price difference is really not that much when you consider the jump in quality.

author: BatMeckley
content: In all seriousness I routinely consider moving out to your part of the world. But every time I weigh all applicable factors LA (almost unfortunately lol) keeps tipping the scales for me.

author: ALXCPH
content: Haha i know, i wasn't commenting on you or your house specifically. But LA is definitely in the top 20 wealthiest cities on earth.

author: ALXCPH
content: you are always welcome here in Denmark, but i don't think you'd enjoy the weather as much 😅

author: Maxim
content: Its GDP alone is almost 3x that of Denmark. 💰But as far as housing goes, Denmark has a population density of 354 people per mi2. LA on the other hand has a pd of *8,485* people per mi2. So, yeah housing is an issue.

author: Maxim
content: As for housing and homelessness, housing prices are higher and homelessness a bigger problem in places where there has been massive government intervention.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was today years old when I realized you’re taking what I say in here WAY too seriously/literally.

And the weather in Denmark is a huge part of why I want to go. Half Canadian/half British. I’m not built for the sun.

author: Rollmottle
content: Both are Automator apps. One on the left spins up a script to date and name my project and create all the necessary directories on my machine and dropbox. The 2nd one opens a workflow that puts my local working drive next to another window of my dropbox drive so I can upload REFs and masters in the right places without having to do a bunch of clicking.

author: CK
content: My question today is should I consider trapping the very top of the room of the vaulted ceiling?  I imagine that is where a lot of low-end energy will accumulate.  I can not find much info on rooms with vaulted ceilings like this, and the room node calculator does not seem to take vaulted ceilings into account (as far as I know). I will likely seek some more advice in the future, and I promise I will try not to throw it all into one post and overwhelm this thread.

author: CK
content: not shown.....WINDOWS. I am excited to have natural light for the first tine in a long time.

author: Zack Hames
content: So...not an expert, but I'd say the vaulted ceilings are a plus and I wouldn't worry about "Trapping" them. I still think you need a cloud solution above your monitors, but I am not sure how you go about that easil with a vault. luckily you own the place 🙂 !

author: Zack Hames
content: you're not putting anything in the vault, so the "low end energy accumulating" isn't going to fuck with whatever is going on down below.

author: CK
content: Definitely gonna build a cloud once I find my listening spot.  I already imagine hanging it will be a challenge!

author: peterlabberton
content: @CK others have more expertise, but my room is very similar in dimensions and has vaulted ceilings (though less steep than yours). I just have a simple cloud above and left the rest bare for now, and I think the extra space above has really helped with low end considering we’re both working with less than ideal floor dimensions. I’d say shoot things out in multiple places with nothing in the room and then go from there, addressing problems as needed. So, maybe trapping in the ceiling? Maybe not! I think you’ve just gotta get in and start messing around to see what’s gonna work.

author: ehutton21
content: Got return on my education dollars today. Used trigonometry to square up my monitors at ~60° angles

author: ehutton21
content: Basically I used my monitor stand to draw out a 30-60-90 triangle for how to position the monitor.

author: ehutton21
content: Where the red, green, and blue lines meet marks half the width of my monitor stand. By treating that as the short leg of the 30/60/90 triangle, I knew that the monitor needed to start to “hang over” the edge of the stand once that long leg (far right green) was just ~7 inches (6.92 something, to be exact-ish). If I did the first two right, I knew the hypotenuse (red) would be 8 inches.

author: ehutton21
content: If I did all that right, I’d be able to pass the tape measure equidistance test.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Here’s the thing… when I give a defeated sigh when I hear someone else’s vocal comp my head already moves about a foot.

Hearing everyone do all these maths to pinpoint a tiny sweet spot feels like that video where the guy has a squeegee on the beach trying to push back in the ocean.

Literally nothing in my room is symmetrical. By design. (No parallel surfaces). It’s not ideal but I’ve don’t alright in it so far.

I’m all for trying to sharpen a scalpel the best we possibly can but also remember the far more important thing is the 8 years of medschool before you start cutting.

author: Will Melones
content:
Valid, but if you start closer to the sweet spot—or at least know where it is—doesn’t that put you in a better position to minimize the damage of moving your head or slouching or whatever? My room is far from symmetrical too, but I’m gonna leverage the variables I *can* control to give myself a hand where I can.

Most importantly, I’ve gotta sit in front of those speakers all day, so they damn well better look cool. I can easily be distracted by the hair to the left that one speaker is cocked, and that’ll hurt productivity. Measuring is peace of mind.

Amen to the 8 years of med school, but damn I wish I’d been mixing in a better room with accurate monitors a few years earlier than I did. It made a difference that I can hear in my work. 10 years ago, probably not so much. You could have handed me Fuller’s espresso machine and I woulda made mud. But in the past 3-5 years I could’ve ruined a few less songs with a clearer picture of what I was hearing.

author: Will Melones
content: And maybe you get better practice in med school if someone gives you early access to a scalpel instead of having you do your dissections with a steak knife

I think my low self esteem leads me to overly compensate to want perfection, when perfection in the grand scheme of things is actually boring and not what people connect with. 

Some hip hop producers I was working with, I would play a lot of the instruments, and they would constantly ask me to play more sloppily or less perfectly because they thought that was way “cooler”. That really thought me a lot, coming from a musician background.

author: Deleted User
content: You probably have more years of experience than I do, but the way I go about this is I only go at it more if I know what can be better and if I know how to make it better. If that is not the case, just move on and don’t exhaust the energy you could have used for another section of the song

author: ALXCPH
content:
Oh ofc. I only do it when I feel I can clearly make it better and know exactly how. It not so much a blindly trying to improve something. It’s more making something so “perfect” nothing sticks out, which can often leave stuff without character. Because all my favourite stuff is not perfect in anyway. 

I think I can compare it to people spending 2 hours in front of a mirror trying to look like they “woke up like this”

author: Deleted User
content: Ahh that makes sense. Why do you feel like it needs to not stick out? Or more so what do you mean when you say something sticks out?

author: ALXCPH
content: I’m constantly learning to just let things be what they are and not care if they are a little off. Because often those are the best bits. It can just be hard to remove ego from that equation when if comes out of oneself

author: ehutton21
content:
Not to be hyperbolic but just as a little update & context: this is my first time actually investing in my work and a singular space for creating, and I finally got to cut some records and demos tonight. 

After the adjustment period to some new implements before the session, I was working quicker and smoother than I think I ever have. I still don’t even have a cloud (I’m aiming to hang it tomorrow night) and I feel like I can hear a pin drop. Artist came away more excited than ever to be working on music, and she was quick to note the improved output and quality on my end: we were able to cut ~3-4 solid demos/ideas in the time it used to take me to cut 1-2. The confidence was through the roof, and it was *fun*.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I know my room is not perfect, but it’s pretty damn good, and when I first started working in it, “sobering” is the right word @Nomograph Mastering 

I thought it was going to be this wonderful sounding, blow my mind type experience. And it sorta was…only in the way that I could really hear what was happening, what the issues were, and what my moves were doing.

When you start actually hearing things, I found it really hard to make stuff better, in a great way. Supercharged my growth (though it was and still is very challenging).

I am super happy to hear that you’re experiencing that clarity and wish you well in the next phase!! Keep going strong friend

author: lystell
content:
It’s funny to me that people say they sound shitty and so. I actually like listening to music in them:) A great record like Petty or something is a blast to me on them. How they sound compared to something else is pointless to me since I don’t like switching between speakers back and forth.
What is the main benefits would you say is having them on the side?

author: Jeremy Klein
content: not being devils advocate, just curious, do you think old music like Petty sounds great on them because everyone mixed on them back in the day. So music is tuned to those speakers?

author: lystell
content: Valid thought! But genre and style  doesn’t really matter.

author: cian riordan
content: On the side because I want them as another perspective. You pick up on different things when you’re not tuning into a big stereo image.

author: cian riordan
content: In our profession, speakers are tools. And what you can do with those tools depends a lot on skill, experience, and the practicality of the tool itself. Let's not get over our skis on this. Just because something measures worse doesn't actually make it bad.

content: Objectively, it did the job then, didn't it?

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: OK but you’re using “objectively” in a different context

author: BatMeckley

author: Rollmottle
content: but what does "objectively" mean in relation to speakers? what are all the criteria we are basing that on?

author: Gerhard Westphalen

author: BatMeckley
content:
💯. But then someone will read a misinformed statement of fact and pass on a speaker that could actually help them make music, “broken” crossover be damned. It feels wrong to frame it that way. 

I feel like a lot of the mods and people doing work on here feel a responsibility from letting objectively bad takes take root and fester.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: So I didn’t frame it in a way that was clear they are perfectly usable speakers that you can get great results from and their problems are what make them great?

author: hyanrarvey
content: I may be on an odd one out here and possibly a hypocrite cause i have big ol fancy speakers. But there really is merrit in learning your speakers like 10+ years

author: Rob Domos
content:
The homies are only disagreeing because they’re in different philosophical frames. Both sides of this convo are full-on right. 

Perspective 1) There are physical parameters for what the platonic ideal of a monitor is, and the closer we can get to that platonic ideal the better.  

Perspective 2)  The reality of engaging with a monitor while working on a mix is more about practical and qualitative experience than it is about ideal and quantitative 

Those are both true. I don’t really see any bad takes

author: BatMeckley
content: I feel like people are new to the word objective

author: austenballard
content: and comes from a context of a lot of bad, oversimplified information on the internet

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Objective in the context of discussing a speaker’s performance is pretty well understood by anyone discussing speakers and it has absolutely nothing to do with popularity etc

author: austenballard
content: But your objective measures are only one set of objective measures

author: Rob Domos
content:
Only with instruments, subjective character is desirable and there are many possible desirable characteristics. 

With monitors, any distinctive character imparted is inherently a deviation from the ideal of transmitting the signal with no coloration whatsoever. 

So that analogy doesn’t exactly work

author: Gerhard Westphalen

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: There’s definitely the subjective aspect of listening and making decisions although I wouldn’t put the design philosophies under the category of subjective performance/evaluation of a speaker. Separate things. Both the subjective and objective “measurements” (referring to a listening test as a subjective measurement) guide the decisions and design philosophy. Yes, it’s inherently about your design approach and if other people like that even if you’re taking a more objective approach and trying to base it solely on “science”. You’ll still have dozens of decisions/trade offs to make

author: Rob Domos
content: Curious about the infinitely small point statement

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: You want a point source. No crossovers or any “size” which ends up affecting other qualities. Obviously impossible and even the best attempts (like spherical omnidirectional speakers) aren’t anywhere close. It would also be pulsing in the sense that the sphere produces sound by increasing in diameter as opposed to moving back and forth. Making something produce sound by that mechanism at any size is already a huge challenge

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Your room presents many challenges, the biggest one being that at low frequencies it’s a square. Your noted issues are entirely predictable

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: It’ll be worth getting someone who really understands the theory on the case. With some position changes and the right kind of treatment in the right places you can likely make things significantly better

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: (Also Kiis don’t punch in any room that I’ve heard, and I’ve heard plenty. They do lots of things well but they are not punchy, or weighty or satisfying down there)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I also definitely would not be afraid to take an EQ and shelf down that high end and up the lows

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: You typically want a 5 or 6 dB drop from call it 40Hz to 10 kHz

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: On a positive note your time domain response (the most important attribute of a room) is mostly great

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I've played around with it with limited success but I also didn't spend that much time. There are a number of ways to do it like with either a mic or feeding directly from your system. The feedback isn't too difficult to deal with if you calculate the filtering, delays, etc but at the end of the day you're just adding a bunch of subs around the room producing sound and making assumptions about acoustics so I suspect you'd end up with a mess even if done ideally

author: Gerhard Westphalen

author: Rollmottle

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For those reading along (and I’ve jammed with G on this) the fundamental problem is that the wave that gets to the back array doesn’t look much like the one that left the front array. Because you know there are all sorts of room interactions and reflections and cancellations on it’s journey

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Even crossing steeply at something like 60Hz I've found things just get weird in the imaging. At one point I had 2 subs for LFE and spent a lot of time placing the second one at different spots around the room but it ultimately ended up back at the front stacked on the other

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
The 3 things you need to move forward
1) What are your constraints? - things you cannot change and must work around
2) what are your goals? - not “to have a studio” - I mean goals like “I want to mix records with these clients at this level in X years”
3) What is your budget?

I want to hear the room and plan, but I need to keep doing this first

@Nomograph Mastering gonna put me in my place I hope

author: Rob Domos
content:
Really controversial take here (based on a few conversations I’ve had with others who felt the opposite of me) but by far the best headphone experience I’ve ever had is with the audeze CRBNs. They’re electrostats and sound to me like the closest thing to what music is really supposed to sound like that I’ve ever heard. 
That said, it sounds nothing like other headphones because THD is an order of magnitude lower. In my mind that’s the best thing ever because it means more unadulterated signal getting mainlined straight into my brain. For most of my friends they find it disorienting that it sounds so unlike everything they’ve ever heard

author: Rob Domos
content: I haven’t heard enough electrostatic headphones to know if it’s the CRBNs themselves that I love or if it’s electrostats in general, but I plan on trying out the new Dan Clark electrostats headphones in the near future and finding out

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: An 8 foot ceiling puts our floor to ceiling primary mode at around 70Hz

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: What we did in @masteredbyjack was stuff between the ceiling joists, but that trades off some isolation which will already be challenging

author: Johnny I
content: Thank you! So to fill the joists, would require taking down the drywall ceiling, essentially extending the ceiling height?

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: So that means you only have one layer of flooring and some insulation between you and the space above

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If it was a fixer upper you could add extra mass to the floor upstairs but it's a pain with doors etc and step ups and down

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I would consider framing out a smaller room for the basement studio to get symmetry and the best possible dimensions

author: peterlabberton
content: Fair to assume any kind of garage (1 car, 2 car, attached/detached) is going to be typically the best choice if studio space is high on the list while house hunting? Clean (ish) slate to work with, solid flooring, etc.

author: peterlabberton
content: (If acoustics of studio is primary over sound isolation)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: A stand alone decent sized garage is the best option for isolation too because you have the structure to support what’s needed and no common walls with living spaces

author: masteredbyjack
content:
@Johnny I as Ruairi says there are many many trade offs...my house is an odd quad level thing, so only the living room is above my studio, all the bedrooms/other spaces are sorta on the "other side". You can't hear the studio in there, but you can definitely hear it if you're in the living room above it. For our family this is fine (wife generally works away from home, I can work late and she can sleep, etc).

In my case this house worked really well for our family, and honestly my room has worked far far better than I expected, it is not the thing that will hold me back for a long time. And if it is that means I've been wildly successful. But more importantly than all of that I have peace that I've made it as good as can be possibly achieved given the space, and that is something I am deeply thankful to Ruairi for, and is maybe the single biggest factor in me being able to just dive into mastering head first. That confidence is key.

In my case for what I do and my wife does it works very well (her office is on the "other side" and can take calls while I work no problem). Which I would argue, the functionality of that I mean, is a huge reason why a studio would be successful too. And we could afford this house, the money to pour into the room, etc. All of that comes into play, so I'd think about that deeply and what that all means to you.

For example, our house is on a beautiful river so I can just pop back there and clear my head during the day. And that's worth a lot to me too and my overall happiness, my wife's, etc. Only you can weigh all that for yourself and where the studio fits

I also stuffed the entire ceiling which seems to have helped a bit IMO for isolation (not just the ceiling in "the studio")...I don't think that has any actual acoustic benefit to the room response but it does seem to mitigate some of the bleed going to the rest of the house.

My preferred listening level is quite low too though, which helps it not being a problem!

author: masteredbyjack
content: Oh also forgot to mention this...Ruairi doesn't know this I don't think but mine was a fixer upper...we put in new floors above and they had to level them with another part of the house so there is like another layer of 3/4'' MDF board or whatever they lay floors on (dense wood), then a LVP type floor which claims to be noise isolating. So that probably plays a big role in how my spot turned out too.

author: Johnny I
content: @masteredbyjack appreciate all of your shares Jack, so helpful to hear real experiences.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: I managed to get down to 64GB but it was with a ton of optimizing preload buffers and distribution on drives. Granted my template was mostly orchestra and usually only running a single mic position. Not much else other than perc

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Wonder how valid this is these days vs like a single AMD EPYC machine

author: LAPhill
content: I’m running everything in surround, with every available articulation loaded, generally between 3 and 7 mics per instrument, coming back into Cubase on about 300 stereo returns (I pared it down recently, can’t remember the exact number). Plus processing per channel and discrete reverbs on 100+ stems so… yeah.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m over here wrestling with left, right, one EQ and one limiter

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Doesn’t help that much because you still have other bottlenecks like hard drive throughout. Even with high IOPS you end up running more than the controllers can handle. Essentially a motherboard and architecture limitation. No amount of CPU + memory + hard drives (both distribution and throughout) will improve this

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Unless you run an extremely high preload buffer but even then

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: What do you mean? Throughput it insanely high these days

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: My template was distributed on 2 M.2 drives and doing purely orchestral work was already close to their limits

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: And I had brought up the EPYC rig due to high RAM, not necessarily just drives

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Think you can hit like 2TB of RAM on those things if not more

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Yeah you could use a high preload buffer to bypass the drives but I don’t know what other bottlenecks you’d hit

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: You’re literally accessing thousands of audio files per second

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: But yeah nowadays these PCIe gen4 drives are pretty insane

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Randomly and that are fragmented all over the place. Not an easy task

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: 500GB - 1TB is about all you can reasonably hold on an M.2 before you saturate it with any decent use (like whatever strings you normally use)

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I think if one were to use four 990 Pro in RAID 0, with 512GB of RAM in one system, the sky is the limit. It’d be an expensive system but could probably handle anything

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: One could just get higher capacity drives in this case

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: No, it’s useless. 500GB of libraries you use will already hit the limits of the drive

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Try to run a full orchestral template off of a single drive and you’re in for a good time

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: There’s “it works” and there’s  “it works for 18 hours a day under load”

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: All of the custom systems I design are max 1TB. Usually 4 or 5 of them for sample drives (OS just on a tiny drive)

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: I’m increasingly a horse built for that course, a big pro tools session just upsets me now

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Right, that’s why I was mainly just suggesting using a single system that has a ton of fast ram vs three systems. I built a VEP rig for someone once and they really wanted to prioritize running the samples in RAM

author: LAPhill
content: There's also robustness. If I lose a drive or, god forbid, a whole computer, I can still transfer things around and get the job done.

author: LAPhill
content: As @Gerhard Westphalen said, I don't go over 1-2TB for sample drives

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: So are all the computers redundant copies of each other?

author: LAPhill
content: Not at all, but I can move things between them if something dies with only a moderate level of swearing

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Guess that’s a plus of multiple rigs still

author: LAPhill
content: A lot of composers have a duplicate rig (or rigs) for their assistants. So, even though they're in use, they could always be swapped out to the main rig in an emergency.

author: LAPhill
content: I don't know if I should say a lot, but it's becoming more common as computers become powerful and the viability of doing it increases

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: But with systems being so simple now I know a few assistants who just take a rig home. 2 trash cans or equivalent and you’re good to go

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Vln 1 legato slurred, vln 1 legato fingered, vln 1 pizz, vln 1 aggressive pizz, vln 1 bartok pizz, vln 1 chamber legato slurred

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: And then you have all of your return busses from VEP. Could be separated by mic positions. Then you have your 100 stems which get bussed down into the stems you deliver

author: LAPhill
content: To whatever degree they deem necessary. Many people don't bother loading some of the really esoteric stuff, if they're doing production music or "epic" music that's mostly longs and shorts. They don't need the fine level of detail that expert craftsman like yours truly demand 😉

author: LAPhill
content: For me, the template is for things that I don't want to setup each time. I have all of the orchestral things set up so that different libraries all behave similarly, responding to the same CC values for mic positions, articulation switching, etc., and also routed for longs and shorts to separate outputs, front and rears separate... things that would completely break my flow if I needed to do that every time.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Even just for mixing it gets ridiculous. Rig A with 60 mics of orch pass A and 60 mics of orch pass B, rig B with all your perc passes, rig C running all the composer stems, rig D recording all the final stems…

author: LAPhill
content: Yeah, but at least mixers can put their buffer size at max

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: Doesn’t help if you’re doing things at 192k and needing to run some rigs at different sample rates (composer stems at 48, delivery stems at 96) 😂

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: And that wasn’t an exaggeration. Real system used by Shawn Murphy for some films

author: jantrit
content:
The million small things that it takes to run a studio properly. Different kinds of tape, adapters and small cables of all kinds, small set of tools for fixing and maintaining, constantly having to fix headphones that break, inline pads etc. 
Bottles of water, selection of teas, coffee, kitchen stuff. All this stuff really is essential and easy to forget. It’s not sexy money to spend. 

Also some of the bigger things like a nice selection of sturdy mic stands and of course as @Rollmottle  says cabling.  I shudder to think how much money I have in looms and cabling.

Edit:
Ok I have some more ahah, more specifically for those doing your own builds. Screws,hardware and sundries!!!You often forget to add this to material costs and man do they add up fast. 

Sets of spare parts (connectors, plugs, switches etc) drum heads, strings, reeds, batteries of all shapes and sizes. 

On that note I’ve got to go and buy some batteries and tape lol

content: Oooo brother hard to remember but it was probably Christmas mass. content: I cried two months ago at a devotional in isreal. There were people from literally all over the world , I’m talking Africans, Latinos, middle easterners, Europeans, etc. all in a living room sitting in a circle singing these prayers at the top of their lungs and changing language with each prayer and I thought to myself “this is what true world peace looks like”

author: Rob Domos
content: It’s often been the communal nature of music that moves me. Seeing the way everyone in a room becomes one when bohemian rhapsody starts for example. Music has the power to unite the hearts of humans into a whole. It’s a lot of what has driven me in this

author: peterlabberton
content: On vocals I’ll often start flat, and then sometimes put on headphones and switch it around while the singer is getting warmed up. author: jantrit
content: Solid core will be super easy to find at Home Depot or lowes and they are absolutely not that expensive (I think my Cr door was 160 or something for a 36” solid core. You can then add even more mass laminating it with mdf (but you only need to do this if it’s the weakest part of the system. Use heavy duty fire door hinges and 4-5 as opposed to the usual 3. A good seal is also key, regular weather stripping and a solid stop will help here. It can be a good idea to install the door first and then close and fix the seals into position after to get the best seal. You can get some fancy bottom seals that lift as you open and then drop back into place and seal when you close but those are not really needed most of the time. The standard solid bottom seals you can get from a hardware store will do. For handles simple pull handles or bars are great if you don’t need the ability to lock. If you do check out solid mortised locksets.

content:
Little update on the room so far! Frames built. Insulation arriving tomorrow and will finish it off. Just need some advice on which route to take. I originally designed a 16cm (6 inch) cloud but now deliberating whether I should swap it for a 20cm (8 inch) panel from the rear wall. Just concerned about weight considerations on the wooden frame. I’ve attached two other pictures of the rear wall. One with two 20cm panels and then other with a 20cm on the bottom and 16cm on the top. 
Should I be worried about lack of performance if I went with the 16cm cloud? Or should I just do the 20cm?

author: Slow Hand
content:
I wanna chime in because I've seen a lot of people with cinder block stands. Naked cinder block stands.

I wrapped mine in thick black felt and now they draw far less attention to themselves. My room is usually low-light and the felt wrap makes them disappear into the room.

Thought I'd mention it in case anyone here doesn't like the sensation of staring at a brick wall while they work.

author: esquinalee
content:
3 issues I’m looking for opinions about:
1) the door on the  “front wall” and how it may affect monitoring
2) the weird triangle wedge in the corner between right wall and ceiling and if that’s something to worry about 
3) potentially the biggest issue which is that there is no door to the stairway from living room to this room. author: Iwan Morgan
content: I’m very jealous of the sun, and being in the trees.  Just noticed you are in Patagonia, did you know that there is a Welsh speaking community there who emigrated in the 1800s? It’s the only place Welsh is spoken outside of Wales. It’s quite weird.

author: peterlabberton
content: That is, and will almost definitely remain, the most surprising thing I’ve heard all week.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I used to volunteer at a talking newspaper for the blind service when I was young and they would get a young Welsh-argentinian coming over every year to help and experience the bright lights of West Wales. Loved the accent.

author: nachomaquieira
content: I didn't know that! Here in Patagonia, there were many immigrants who came, especially from Germany and Switzerland, several years ago already. I didn't know about the Welsh community, but it doesn't surprise me either. The weather here in winter is harsh like there, very cold, snow, few hours of daylight, and lots of rain/snow and very very little sun. But days in spring and summer are in full swing,  we have from 5 am to 10 pm sunlight, during the day you're in a t-shirt, you can swim in the lakes, and at night it cools down a bit.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I think the idea was to escape English rule, and start a new religious community only problem was none of the early emigrants were skilful farmers, but I think they made friends with the indigenous people. https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patagonian_Welsh#:~:text=The%20Welsh%20people%20first%20arrived,Wales%20and%20the%20Chubut%20Valley.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: You can use any fabric that breathes. How do you know if it breathes? Put it up to your mouth and breathe through it

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There are advantages to the professional acoustic fabrics

- more durable
- fire rated
- they hang better etc

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Guildford of Maine is the (expensive) class leader here

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Knowing what I know it’s the only thing I would choose to use on my own builds

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: To contain fibers consider using a thin layer of Dacron (fluffy white nylon teddy bear stuffing)

author: esquinalee

author: Adam Thein
content: I got mine through Magna Fabrics (Larry Fink).  It was a little informal in that we exchange emails and he sent a long list of what he had in stock.  Apparently he gets the fabrics from leftover corporate builds and so you can get deals very below market rates on fabrics.  You'll want to research the fabrics he has availble on the manufacturer sites to make sure they meet the acoustic transparency rating and any fire resistance you want.

author: Rollmottle
content: My whole space is built around eliminating what distracts me (all my cable management OCD for example) and marrying that with my idea of a space that is inviting and comfortable to not only work in, but also to simply be in. It's most definitely a studio but I wanted it to not shout "studio." Moved away from the dark and drudgey studio black and went for lots of white, bright colors, natural wood, warm light, as much open space as possible. It was all a matter of knowing what I like and definitely don't like and leaning all the way in.

author: Will Pragnell
content:
Okay here's my take on the differences:
- Cian's setup sounded slightly more mid forward, Anthony's was a little more "smiley face" in comparison (not really, just compared to Cian's)
- I felt like the longer listening difference at Anthony's place worked better for me with those speakers
- Could hear a little more detail in the mids at Cian's place, whereas I preferred feel of the low end (a little tighter and punchier) at Anthony's
For my purposes (mastering, biasing towards dance / bass music) Anthony's felt right, but I'd be more than happy to work out of Cian's spot too... I'd probably just experiment with a larger listening triangle. Both great rooms!

author: jonmatteson
content: My wonderful wife is letting me take over our living room so that I can have bigger sessions with more collaborators. I’m about to treat this room with some panels I already have and was wondering if I should I hang my 8x4x6 inch thick panel or 6x4x4 inch thick panel as the cloud in here? I have approximately 4 1/2 feet before the beam and will use whatever I don’t use as a cloud as a gobo behind me. Room is 12 feet wide.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
The smaller cloud will be good, same rules as I suggested in the last room. In some similar rooms I got lucky and was able to straddle the cloud(s) from beam to beam and avoid any drilling and mounting. Might be worth doing tests and if it works you could have John Hunter make you two clouds optimized for the straddle. Worth noting that A frame ceilings can do some really fucky things in the mids and lows

Left and right first relection are crucal, use you gobos again - yes you'll lose one window but worth it

I wouldn't bother with any rear treatement to start

author: jonmatteson
content: Ok thank you for the guidance! I will try some stuff out. Definitely a little weird in the low end with no treatment right now so hopefully the cloud helps that out a bit

author: Slow Hand
content:
Practically speaking, it's a simple audio effect that turns your audio into metallic-sounding harmonics. It gets atonal real fast 😃.

Technically speaking it multiplies your audio signal by a modulator signal and spits out the sum and difference of the two signals. The two outputs tend to not be harmonically related and end up clashing in ways that sound "metallic". Lots of beating frequencies, and extra sidebands, and aliasing (if you're digital).

author: Deleted User
content: Basically they resonate out of phase to the tuned frequency and thus dim it down. The dampening material behind it helps to broaden the q factor I think

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The membrane is converting air  pressure variations at low frequency into heat, nothing to do with phase

author: popthetrunk
content: Mirrors are great! Better iops, at the cost of less space, raidz2 can be really great as well, did you try it out and say nah?

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: just seemed like a good way to go given that I'm using four drives in the pool for data

author: Bryan DiMaio

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I guess unless you lose both drives in a single vdev lol

author: popthetrunk
content: Did you schedule smart tests? I think I saw you posted about refurbed drives, we’re they refurb or recertified by manufacturer? If refurb I would not do a scrub weekly

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I think the default is weekly smart tests

author: popthetrunk
content: serverpartdeals.com has two day shipping and manu recertified drives for a failure. Death of disk is a fact of life. The ‘bathtub curve’ is pretty classic, some stuff dies and then a long period of stability, and then stuff dies all at once, so being pre emptive with replacement after a while and monitoring your stuff is a good idea.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Yeah I've been thinking about getting a couple cold spares

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: wanted to get it all up and running to make sure I'm not totally inept at this first

author: popthetrunk
content: No you want scrubs, maybe do every 6-8 weeks for those, but they are intense and on something like shucked drives or just a shitty specimen it can make your pool very sad. Whatever you do, do not use SMR drives for ZFS

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: yep learned that one from a friend, I've got all CMR

author: popthetrunk
content: Dude protools is harder than storage administration. You totally got this, it’s just new to you

author: popthetrunk
content: Also worth noting, if you wanted to get 2 more drives you can make them 3 way mirrors so you have 2 disk redundancy in each mirror vdev

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: and for example if I'm using all 12TB drives that would give me 12TB more space?

author: popthetrunk
content: No, just redundancy, if you added another 2 way vdev it would give you more space

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: but changing to something like raidz2 would?

author: popthetrunk
content: Yes, you would have to destroy your pool before remaking it like that

content: oh dang I didn't know it was hot swappable

author: Brian Reynolds
content: With a cloud of that size and weight. One stud and 8 points of contact. Assuming the other 4 are anchored with some sort of drywall anchor or something of the like is more than enough

author: Brian Reynolds

author: Brian Reynolds
content: Stay a bit uncomfortable and careful and you'll be good

author: cian riordan
content: is that the f150 lightning? how do you like that thing?

author: kylem
content:
Yes! Got it a few months back. I’m in love with it. So much room in the interior. I definitely wouldn’t have bought it if we still lived up in the city, it’s too big…but we’re down near the beach now and spend a ton of time there. I surf and love camping. Having the bed for projects around the house has been great. And the tech is really cool. Being able to plug in to regular outlets anywhere on the truck is awesome. Haven’t had any power outages yet but I’m setup if the house goes down to plug in the fridge + a few things to keep us going for a few days. Also, the frunk has a drain plug and you can use it like a cooler.

If anyone is in the market for one, the incentives are ridiculous atm. I’m paying the same amount on this lease that I was for my Mazda cx5 and that thing is basically 1/3 the price. I guess ford has had trouble getting people to buy & lease these? But with the EV credit + fords employee pricing it’s a steal.

author: Rollmottle
content: EV tax credit ends Sep 30 so if you want a deal, act now because the incentive is going away

author: Rollmottle
content: (The federal one at least is, there are states that have their own so YMMV depending on your state...and some manufacturers may continue to subvene SOME incentive, but free $7,500 from Uncle Sam for either manufacturer or consumer is going away)

author: kylem
content: I feel like ford is going to have to keep doing something to entice people. As someone who has always been against the whole ford brand, the only reason I came over was because of the incentives
